body:
### Problem

Hi there!
I've found, that when I run NeoVim with konsole's TERMs, it doesn't properly work with alternate screen (or how is it called right way).

It looks like nvim doesn't even start alternate_screen mode.

And, of course, screen content doesn't restore on exit.

And with `xterm-*` TERMs nvim behaves fine, but I'd like to use TERMs that better corresponds to the terminal, than "generic" xterm ones...

Tested with `nvim -u NONE`, `nvim -u NONE -i NONE`, `nvim -u NORC` and `nvim --clean`, reproduced every time

### Steps to reproduce

0. use Konsole or Yakuake (they share same engine)
1. TERM=konsole nvim --clean
2. notice nvim doesn't entered alternate screen mode
3. `:q`
4. notice that terminal content doesn't restored, and there is content of nvim buffer on the screen, despite you're already exited

### Expected behavior

nvim enters alternate_screen mode on start, and leave it on exit (so terminal content would be restored)

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

v0.10.0-dev-653+gfbeef0d4e-dirty

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

no, 9.0.1403

### Operating system/version

Gentoo Linux

### Terminal name/version

Konsole 22.12.3

### $TERM environment variable

konsole, konsole-256color, konsole-direct

### Installation

built from git HEAD using ebuild ov 9999 version from official gentoo repo

Does this issue still exist if you use the appimage from the Releases page?

> Does this issue still exist if you use the appimage from the Releases page?

Yup.
Both with nightly and stable appimages

I found interesting thing.

I suddenly surprisinngly found that I have `TERMINFO_DIRS=/usr/share/st/terminfo` environment variable.

I digged a bit and found that it (of course) set by env-snippet, installed by `st` shell.

I personally can't remember how did it appeared on my laptop (whether I installed it manually to test, or it was dependency of something I used before), but still.

So, when I unset that variable, nvim starts to work normally with konsole TERMs :shrug:


Anyway, maybe it worth to patch nvim to always try to search terminfos at "default" terminfo paths even if this variable is set?

> always try to search terminfos at "default" terminfo paths even if this variable is set?

That kind of subtle behavior usually leads to the opposite problem when the setting is intentional.

# Proposal

But we should probably show an error if TERM is set but we couldn't find a terminfo file on the system.

>I digged a bit and found that it (of course) set by env-snippet, installed by st shell.

`TERMINFO_DIRS` should only be set to this value when actually using `st`. This is likely a bug with how `st` is packaged on Gentoo. I suggest filing an issue with your packager to address this.

`ssh` shows this when using an invalid (read: no matching terminfo entry) `TERM` value:

```
$ TERM=blah ssh remote
warning: Could not set up terminal.
warning: TERM environment variable set to 'blah'.
```

Seems like a good template for us to use as well.
